Trial_Design.evidence: Five surgeons at five sites have followed 189 patients (216 hips) for a minimum of 10 years and average of 10.3 years (range, 10–12.4 years) comparing alumina ceramic bearings (144 hips) with cobalt chrome-on-polyethylene bearings (72 hips).

Participants.evidence: Five surgeons at five sites have followed 189 patients (216 hips)

Intervention.evidence: comparing alumina ceramic bearings (144 hips) with cobalt chrome-on-polyethylene bearings (72 hips).

Objective.evidence: We asked whether ceramic bearings have equal or superior survivorship compared with that for metal-on-polyethylene at longer followup

Method_Outcome.evidence: We determined Kaplan-Meier survivorship of the bearing surface and implant systems and collected radiographic and clinical data.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Five surgeons at five sites have followed 189 patients (216 hips)

Result_Outcome.evidence: Revisions for any reason occurred in 10.5% of the control patients and 3.1% of the patients with alumina bearings.

Harms.evidence: Squeaking occurred in two of 144 hips (1.4%) of the patients with ceramic bearings.
